Herbie: The Love Bug, sometimes known as simply Herbie, is a 2009 American action-adventure sports comedy film directed by Tim Hill. Based on the characters created by Gordon Buford, the film is based on a screenplay written by Will McRobb and Chris Viscardi, David Hoselton, Tony Gilroy and Pamela Pettler, and a story written by Pettler and Thomas Lennon. A reboot to the original Herbie series, it stars Emily Blunt, Kevin Hart, Fran Drescher, David Hyde Pierce, Hayden Christensen, Jason Schwartzman, Christina Ricci, James Van Der Beek and David Strathairn.

In the film, college graduate Kathleen Richardson discovers Herbie in a junkyard, beaten and covered in grime, and decides to rescue it and restore him to his former glory, keeping him from corrupt racing executive Dan Breusten, and his egotistical professional NASCAR racer son Bergan. In the process, Herbie receives heavy modifications to his design to qualify for the upcoming race in Los Angeles.

Following the unsatisfactory box office performance of Herbie: Fully Loaded in 2006, Walt Disney Pictures sold the rights to the Herbie franchise to NBCUniversal for $950 million. With the acquisition complete, Universal Pictures announced a reboot to the Herbie series in 2006, effectively resetting the series altogether. Tim Hill was revealed to direct in 2008. Principal photography commenced in Los Angeles.

Herbie: The Love Bug premiered on July 30, 2009 in Los Angeles, and was released on August 14 in the United States by Universal Pictures. It received acclaim from critics, with praise for its higher production values, performances of the cast (particularly that of Blunt, Hart, Christensen, Beek and Strathairn), cinematography, plot, action sequences, screenplay, and story, though criticized the runtime. It grossed $561.4 million worldwide on its budget of $100-135 million, becoming the eighth-highest-grossing film of 2009.

Cast[edit | edit source]

Emily Blunt as Kathleen Richardson, a college graduate living in San Francisco who finds Herbie while at a junkyard.

Kevin Hart as Bruce Brown, Kathleen's boyfriend who is a mechanic.

James Van Der Beek as Bergan Breusten, a NASCAR driver who has an inflated ego.

David Strathairn as Dan Breusten, Bergan's father and the executive for the NASCAR event.

Fran Drescher as Maria Richardson, Kathleen's mother.

David Hyde Pierce as Derek Richardson, Kathleen's father.

Hayden Christensen as Marcus, Kathleen's best friend.

Jason Schwartzman as Noah, Kathleen's friend who is a professional basketball player.

Christina Ricci as Natalie, Kathleen's tomboyish friend who is a mechanic. She works with Bruce at the car repair dealer.

Production[edit | edit source]

Development and writing[edit | edit source]

In 2006, following the release of Herbie: Fully Loaded the year before, Walt Disney Pictures was dissatisfied with the financial performance of the film. Making just $144 million at the box office against a budget of $50 million, it was considered both a financial failure in both regions of the world. With the disappointment, Walt Disney Pictures was planning on putting the Herbie franchise up for potential grabs. Potential buyers included Viacom, TimeWarner, and Sony Pictures.

However, NBCUniversal was the selected buyer, and purchased the rights to Herbie for a total cost of $950 million, becoming one of the largest acquisitions in the entertainment industry. With the acquisition finalized in March of 2006, Universal Pictures announced that a revival of the series would begin production later in the year. Production officially began on September 25, 2006, with Will McRobb and Chris Viscardi signing to write the screenplay.

Tim Hill was confirmed to direct the film, now with the title Herbie: The Love Bug, in 2008.

Visual effects and animation[edit | edit source]

The visual effects for the film were produced by Double Negative, Rhythm & Hues Studios, and Industrial Light & Magic. CGI animation was produced by ILM and Sony Pictures Imageworks. The CGI animation was used in scenes that featured Herbie.

Music[edit | edit source]

John Debney was confirmed to do the score for the film, after Christopher Lennertz declined the offer. The soundtrack was released by Republic and Interscope Records on September 2, 2009.
